hints.content: Start by understanding what an uncommon subsequence is. An uncommon subsequence is a subsequence that exists in one string but not in the other. Think about how you can identify subsequences in the given strings.
Consider the lengths of the two strings. If one string is longer than the other, the longer string itself could be a candidate for the longest uncommon subsequence. Why might that be the case?
If both strings are identical, then every subsequence of one string is also a subsequence of the other. In this case, what should you return?
When the two strings are different, the longer string will definitely have subsequences that are not present in the shorter string. Think about how you can determine which string is longer.

If the lengths of both strings are the same but the strings are different, both strings can be considered as uncommon subsequences. What would be the length of the longest uncommon subsequence in this case?
Make sure to handle edge cases where one or both strings might be empty. What should you return if either string is empty?
Review the constraints given in the problem. Both strings will have lengths between 1 and 100. How does this affect your approach to finding the solution?
Think about the return value. You need to return -1 if there is no uncommon subsequence. Under what conditions would you return -1?
To summarize your findings: if the strings are the same, return -1; if they are different, return the length of the longer string. How can you implement this logic in your code?

Finally, write a simple check to compare the two strings. If they are equal, return -1; otherwise, return the maximum length of the two strings. This will give you the length of the longest uncommon subsequence.

questionNotes: An uncommon subsequence exists in exactly one of the two strings.
Return -1 if both strings are identical.
The length of the longest uncommon subsequence can be the length of the longer string if they are different.
Constraints: 1 <= a.length, b.length <= 100; both strings consist of lowercase English letters.
